College of Chemistry and Materials Jiangxi Agricultural University Nanchang 330045 PR China Renewable energy has attracted widespread interest for fuel resources and environmental concerns. In this work, an eco-friendly novel catalyst (VSCS) was prepared from Vernicia montana seed shell via direct sulfonation. Subsequently, the catalytic performance was evaluated through the transesterification. The catalyst was characterized in order to elucidate the relationship between its catalytic performance and physicochemical structure. The VSCS catalyst achieved a high biodiesel yield (>90%) for glyceryl trioleate and Waste Cooking Oil (WCO). The catalyst possesses a considerable number of stable -SO3H, a sufficient quantity of -COOH, and exhibits a high acid content. Consequently, a 98.58% yield of biodiesel for WCO was obtained via VSCS 450 °C catalysis, and it reached 99.70% at the optimal conditions (catalyst amount of 9.6 wt.%, WCO/MeOH molar ratio of 1:30, at 120 °C for 8 h). Furthermore, an artificial neural network (ANN) model demonstrated the excellent performance for the prediction of FAME yield. Mechanism analysis shows that the synergistic effect of oxygen-containing group and sulfonic acid group, as well as facilitate physical adsorption, greatly facilitates transesterification. Green metrics indicated its sustainability, with low E-factor (0.609), high atom economy (90.60%) and desirable RME (0.621). Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Biodiesel Transesterification Heterogeneous catalyst Vernicia montana seed shell Waste Cooking Oil Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Biodiesel is a clean, renewable, and non-polluting green energy source [1–3]. It has notable advantages over traditional fossil fuels, including a high flash point, excellent cetane number performance, low cooling tendencies, and a reasonable calorific value [4]. These characteristics not only enhance the safety and stability of biodiesel during storage and transportation, but also demonstrate notable environmental compatibility. This can lead to a considerable reduction in CO2 emissions by 78%, thereby making a substantial contribution to sustainable development and environmental protection [5]. A lot of researches has been dedicated to biodiesel production, encompassing a wide range of disciplines, from the investigation of raw materials to the development of production technologies [6]. For raw materials, waste cooking oil represents an optimal feedstock for the preparation of biodiesel: (1) Approximately 5 million tons (MT) of WCO is generated annually in China’s large and medium cities [7]; (2) A remarkable degree of conversion efficiency, statistical data show that an average of 1.2 tons of waste cooking oil can be converted into 1 ton of biodiesel [6]; (3) The environmental damage caused by waste cooking oil is irreparable and manifests itself in problems such as water and soil pollution, which are challenging to control. Therefore, the conversion of waste cooking oil into biodiesel is a viable solution to the environmental problems, while facilitating the production of a valuable resource. Transesterification is a crucial step in the production of biodiesel. It involves the chemical reaction between animal and plant fats and short-chain alcohols like methanol and ethanol.The process offers numerous advantages, including the abundance of raw materials, well-established reaction technology, easy industrial-scale production, efficient utilization of waste oil and grease, and resource recycling. However, there are drawbacks to consider. The quality of raw materials must meet stringent standards. Raw materials like oil and grease often contain high levels of free fatty acids and water, which can negatively impact the reaction by promoting unwanted side reactions [8,9]. The Pre-esterification process, which is usually carried out to reduce the acidity of the oils, is a necessary process before transesterification. The catalysts prepared in these works have shown excellent performance in the esterification reaction [10–13]. There are three primary technical approaches to catalytic transesterification: biological enzyme catalysis, homogeneous catalysis, and heterogeneous catalysis. Enzyme catalysis is regarded as favorable because of its environmental friendliness and high product purity. However, significant challenges, including high cost, sluggish reaction rates, and inherent volatility of enzymes, impede their widespread adoption in industrial manufacturing processes. Homogeneous catalytic technology has been widely used because of its high catalytic efficiency, short reaction time, and low cost [2]. Currently, acid-base homogeneous catalysis remains the predominant production method in industry. However, the intricacies of the separation process, saponification reactions, susceptibility to free fatty acids (FFA) and moisture, rigorous reaction conditions and corrosiveness to equipment have also come to the fore. These issues fail to align with the environmental standards of green chemistry. In comparison with, homogeneous catalysis, heterogeneous catalysts are widely used in a variety of industrial reactions. During transesterification, solid acid catalysts exhibit significant advantages over other types of catalysts, including but not limited to non-corrosiveness, non-saponification, and ease of separation and recovery. In the early days, the majority of the solid acid catalysts, such as sulfated zirconia, zeolite and mixed oxides, focused on metal-based catalysts, however, these catalysts faced challenges such as harsh reaction conditions [6] limited reusability, and difficulty in degrading [14,15], which exacerbated the complexity of the biodiesel production process and drove up the production costs . In recent years, biomass-based solid acids have gradually emerged due to their significant advantages such as low cost, easy availability and stable performance, and are regarded as a solid acid with great potential. It is worth mentioning that biomass is mainly composed of carbonaceous components such as lignin, hemicellulose and cellulose [16]. The differences in the content, structure and carbonization process of these components will have a significant impact on the properties of the final carbon, which give diversity and flexibility to the functionalization of solid acid catalysts. Therefore, this area has attracted great interest from researchers worldwide [16,17]. However, some cases have shown that carbon-based solid acid catalysts have low catalytic performance for the conversion of oils and fats to fatty acid methyl esters [1], presumably due to insufficient loading of sulfonic acid group and insufficient affinity for substrates. How to improve the loading capacity of sulfonic acid group and the affinity for reaction substrates has become a major problem for carbon-based solid acid catalysts. Encouragingly, the results showed that solid acid catalysts made from agricultural and forestry wastes achieved a significant increase in acid loading [17,18]. This breakthrough may be attributed to the selection of biomass materials and the optimization of the catalyst preparation process, in which oxygen-containing groups and aromatic carbons were selectively retained. It not only enhances the polarity of the catalyst, but also greatly increases the loading of sulfonic acid group. At the same time, the loose and porous structure of the catalyst provides sufficient contact area and reaction channels for methanol, which lays a solid foundation for the improvement of catalytic efficiency. As mentioned in several articles the Vernicia montana seed shell has lots of lignin content (45 wt.%−70 wt.%) and potassium salt (content of K +: 2 wt.%−5 wt.%), which provides a possible application space for the preparation of solid acid carbon sulfonic catalysts [19,20]. Herein, we conducted exploratory experiments to prepare solid acid catalysts using Vernicia montana seed shell as raw materials. Green chemistry aims at making chemistry more sustainable by minimizing environmental impact, enhancing efficiency, and promoting the use of renewable resources [21–23]. Albert Matlack and John Andraos, have noted that researchers increasingly draw vague conclusions that chemical processes are “green” without providing quantitative evidence to support such claims [24]. In this context, green chemistry metrics have emerged as indispensable tools in biodiesel production research [25,26], serving as quantitative benchmarks to evaluate the environmental footprint, operational efficiency, and sustainability of chemical processes. These metrics align with the twelve principles of green chemistry, enabling chemists to systematically assess the “greenness” of a process [27,28]. Key metrics highlighted in recent studies include atom economy (AE), material recovery parameter (MRP), the inverse stoichiometric factor (1/SF), and reaction mass efficiency (RME). Graphical tools like radial pentagon diagrams visualize these five metrics simultaneously, which aids in comparing different processes [23,29]. Optimizing reaction conditions to enhance these metrics directly addresses the dual goals of minimizing resource consumption and waste generation. Such advancements underscore the pivotal role of green chemistry metrics in guiding the design of more sustainable biodiesel synthesis pathways [25,30]. Over the past years, the artificial neural networks (ANNs) have emerged as prominent computational tools for modeling and forecasting optimization outcomes across diverse experimental studies, particularly in the realm of biodiesel production [31]. Biodiesel synthesis involves complex nonlinear interactions among parameters such as feedstock type, catalyst concentration, reaction temperature, and mixing time, which necessitate precise modeling for yield enhancement and cost optimization. As a machine learning approach derived from biological neural systems, ANNs emulate information processing through interconnected nodes that simulate synaptic interactions, making them well-suited to capture the intricate nonlinear relationships in biodiesel production processes. These adaptive networks dynamically adjust connection weights during supervised learning phases through iterative parameter optimization, ultimately constructing predictive frameworks with minimized prediction errors [31,32]. In biodiesel research, ANNs have been increasingly applied to model transesterification reactions, forecast biodiesel yield under varying operational conditions, and optimize multi-objective parameters, while addressing challenges like feedstock variability and catalyst efficiency. Such applications highlight how ANNs enable researchers to design cost-effective and environmentally friendly biodiesel production protocols. In this work, a sustainable solid acid catalyst was synthesized from agricultural and forestry waste biomass and a comprehensive characterization of the catalyst was conducted to ascertain the correlation between its catalytic activity and its physicochemical properties in transesterification reactions of waste cooking oils. In addition, an artificial neural network (ANN) model was developed for the purpose of predictive and the sustainability and environmental impact of the reaction were assessed using green chemistry metrics. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The Vernicia montana seed shell was collected from rural areas in southern Jiangxi, China. Waste Cooking Oil was collected from a restaurant located in our school. Analytical reagent methanol, ethanol, ethyl acetate, potassium hydroxide, hydrochloric acid, concentrated sulfuric acid, and anhydrous sodium sulfate were commercially available and were used as received. Glyceryl trioleate was of industrial grade purchased from Heowns Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd (Tianjin China). 2.2 Catalyst preparation Firstly, the Vernicia montana seed shell was cut into small pieces and dried at a constant temperature of 105 °C for 24 h. Subsequently, the dried sample was finely pulverized to achieve the desired degree of powdering using a grinding machine. Then, the finely pulverized biomass material was placed in a muffle furnace with a 3.5 h carbonization (300 °C, 450 °C, 600 °C and 750 °C). After through a 200-mesh sieve, the carbonized biochar-based materials (VSC) were directly placed in a concentrated sulfuric acid environment to introduce sulfonic acid groups (-SO3H) into the material. In this process, 40 g of the VSC powder was immersed in 200 mL of H2SO4(98 %) and heated at 120 °C for 16 h with a stirring to obtain a black solution containing VSCS. Finally, the solid acid was stored in a dryer for later use, mark as VSCS 300 °C, VSCS 450 °C, VSCS 600 °C, VSCS 750 °C, respectively. The schematic diagram of the preparation process for solid acid VSCS was shown in Fig. 1 . 2.3 Characterizations methods The carbon precursor, WCO and Biodiesel were characterized using a number of varying methods. FT-IR spectral (Spectrum Two) studies were carried out in the wavenumber range of 4000–500 cm−1. Thermogravimetric Analyzer (TGA/DSC1) recorded the degradation behavior of a 5–10 mg samples in a platinum crucible, throughout the process under 1.6 bar, 19.8 mL/min nitrogen protection environment, heating from 30 °C to 800 °C at a rate of 20 °C /min, and monitoring the weight of the sample in real-time to obtain the TG and DTG data graphs. Determination of the Brauner–Emmet–Teller (BET) specific surface area and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) pore size distribution was conducted by N2 adsorption using (PMI-1567, BSD), after degassing at 150 °C and N2 atmosphere for 240 min. Organic elemental analyzer (Flash Smart) was employed for the analysis of C, H, N, S content in the Vernicia montana seed shell carbon and catalyst. The surface morphology of the catalyst was analyzed using scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Zeiss Sigma 300) operated with an accelerating voltage of 3.00 KV. The 1H NMR spectrums of WCO and biodiesel were recorded on a spectrometer (Bruker Avance III 400 MHz) using tetramethylsilane (TMS) as an internal standard. The pH meter was used to test pH value: Disperse 0.1 g solid acid in 50 mL deionized water at room temperature, and then directly measure the pH value of the dispersion system with a pH meter. Acid-base neutralization titration was used to test the acid content: 0.1 g solid acid was decentralized to 50 mL saturated NaCl solution at room temperature, 2–3 drops of phenolphthalein indicator, and the acid content was titrated with KOH (0.05 M). The acid content was calculated using the Eq. (1). (1) A c i d i c a c t i v e ( m m o l / g ) = C K O H × V K O H m c a t ( m m o l / g ) 2.4 Transesterification experiments and ANN model An acid-catalyzed transesterification of WCO (or glyceryl trioleate) was carried out in a 50 mL Schlenk tube with adding 10 g of WCO (or glyceryl trioleate) and the required amount of methanol and solid acid catalyst. Then the Schlenk tube was immersed in a preheated oil bath with stirring. When the predetermined reaction time was reached, the Schlenk tube was removed from the oil bath and cooled to room temperature. 5 mL Ethyl acetate was then added to the reaction mixture to reduce the viscosity of the system. The solid catalyst was then separated by centrifugation. Methanol and ethyl acetate were removed by rotary evaporation. Glycerol was removed by washing with 5 mL hot water, then 10 mL ethyl acetate was used to dissolve the top layer product and the aqueous phase was removed. Finally, the ethyl acetate solution was dried with anhydrous sodium sulphate and then FAME was obtained by rotary evaporation. The yield of biodiesel is calculated using the Eq. (2). (2) Y i e l d ( % ) = m a s s o f B i o d i e s e l ( F A M E ) m a s s o f W C O × 100 ( % ) And the conversion of biodiesel is calculated using the Eq. (3) [33,34]. A − O C H 3 (3.66 ppm) denotes the integration value of the methyl esters, and A C H 2 (2.30 ppm) is the integration value of the methylene protons (1H NMR). (3) C o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = 2 × A − O C H 3 3 × A C H 2 × 100 ( % ) A standard ANN architecture comprises three computational strata: data reception layer, feature transformation layer, and decision output layer. The model development process requires partitioning experimental datasets into distinct subsets (methanol-oil molar ratio, catalyst amount, reaction temperature, and reaction time), typically allocating 70% for weight calibration and 30% for predictive performance evaluation. Detailed Model training program is provided in the supplementary materials. Ten green chemistry metrics (Yield, AE, 1/SF, MRP, RME, E, PMI, SI, RI, and RP) were calculated and applied to evaluate the process. All information and calculation formulas related to green metrics are provided in the supplementary materials. In catalyst cycling experiments, the recovered catalyst was subjected to two-three washes with ethyl acetate, followed by drying at a constant temperature of 105 °C. Subsequently, the cycling experiment was conducted under optimized reaction conditions. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 pH and acid content As shown in Fig. 2 , there were significant differences in the pH values and acid content of the solid acids derived from different carbon precursors. In particular, VSCS 300 °C exhibited the most notable performance in terms of pH value and acid content (3.65 mmol/g). As the carbonization temperature increased, the pH value of the VSCS gradually increased, and the acid content of solid acid also decreased. This phenomenon may be attributed to the tendency of lower carbonization temperatures to retain a greater proportion of organic components, thereby facilitating the loading of sulfonic acid group and the retention of carboxylic acid groups [35–37]. Although the acidity of the catalyst is the main factor affecting catalytic activity, but it was also influenced by other factors (such as the nature of the active acid site, stability…). 3.1.2 FT-IR spectra FT-IR spectra of VSC precursors and VSCS were recorded under the condition of a wavenumber range of 4000–500 cm−1. As shown in Fig. 3 , the absorption band near 3400 cm−1 associated with the -O-H stretching vibration may originate from the hydroxyl group retained in the precursor material and the adsorption of water molecules from the air. The absorption peaks at 1165 cm−1, 892 cm−1, and 595 cm−1 were observed, providing compelling evidence for the effective sulfonation of VSCS. The absorption peak in 1596 cm−1 was corresponded to the characteristic peak of cellulose. As the temperature of the carbonization process increased, it gradually weakened and disappeared. On the other hand, the absorption peak in 1600–1550 cm−1, associated with the aromatic C = C that formed through the aromatization of cellulose and lignin, as Ezebor and Estevez reported on the same phenomenon [38]. Additionally, both VSC and VSCS exhibited a vibration band related to the C = O from -COOH at 1705 cm−1, which was due to the oxidation of residual cellulose by sulfuric acid during the sufonation process [39]. These carboxyl groups have the potential to enhance the acid content and lipophilicity of the catalyst, which were very helpful for triglyceride transesterification. However, the peak of C = O intensity was larger in (a) and (b), whereas it was weaker in (c) and (d). These findings indicated that the elevated carbonization temperature promoted the removal of cellulose, resulting in a decrease in the formation of carboxyl groups. Because of the lack of these carboxyl groups, catalysts VSCS 600 °C and VSCS 750 °C may have slightly poorer performance than VSCS 450 °C. Furthermore, the peaks of 1008 cm−1 can be clearly observed in (a), and it was the absorption peak of the O-S bond, which indicated the presence of L-OSO3H formed by the esterification of hydroxyl groups in the carbon material with sulfuric acid during the sulfonation process [40]. L-OSO3H is very unstable, because it could transform into SO2(OCH3)2 with methanol. 3.1.3 TG and DTG The resulting thermogravimetric analysis (TG/DTG) curve was presented in Fig. 4 , and this TG process can be roughly divided into four different stages. Initially, at the region of 100–150 °C, the weight loss was attributed to the desorption of water molecules [41]. Subsequently, the dissociation and desorption were caused by sulfonic acid group (-SO3H) marked in yellow [42]. Afterwards, at the region of 350–450 °C, decomposition was due to aromatic carbon. Ultimately, the inorganic carbon backbone structure underwent decomposition [43]. It can be observed that the advancement of the weight loss peak of the sulfonic acid group in Fig. 4 (a) was due to that a portion of the sulfonic acid group was connected to VSCS 300 °C by O-S bond. Thus, this kind of L-OSO3H is also poor thermal stability. Moreover, the aromatic carbon was formed on the basis of the aromatization of cellulose and lignin at higher temperatures, and sulfonation on aromatized carbon materials will help form more stable carbon sulfonic acids. 3.1.4 BET The porous parameters derived from the isotherms were listed in Table 1 . Compared with before and after carbonization, the specific surface area of the carbon material increased significantly after carbonization. This phenomenon may be attributed to the dissolution of organic matter retained in the carbon material, as well as alkaline mineral salts in the sulfuric acid, which resulted in an increased number of pores. The VSC 300 °C, a significant amount of cellulose has been broken down into small molecules by sulfuric acid and formed a hollow like structure. Thus, its surface area was significantly higher to that of other VSCS. The VSCS 300 °C had the largest weight loss in the TG data, which may also be due to its loose structure after sulfonation. This indicates that the catalyst has minimal thermal. In contrast, the higher carbonization temperature resulted in the breakdown of carbon skeleton and the more of wood tar would be formed [44]. The formation of wood tar can cause the pores of the catalyst to be blocked, as a result, the specific surface area decreased. As the carbonization temperature continued to increase, however, the wood tar could break down into smaller molecules compounds, which can remove from VSC to sulfuric acid solution. Therefore, the surface area of other VSCS showed a gradual increase from 450 °C to 750 °C of carbonization temperature. 3.1.5 Elemental analysis The elemental analysis of samples was presented in Table 2 . A comparative analysis of four VSC precursors revealed a consistent decline in hydrogen content and H/C ratio as the carbonization temperature increased. This suggested that a relatively lower carbonization temperature may be more effective in preserving aromatic polycyclic carbons and catalytic-promoting groups. The hydrogen and carbon content were diminished following sulfonation, which may be attributed to the oxidation of the polycyclic aromatic carbon skeleton by concentrated sulfuric acid during the sulfonation process. Conversely, the sulfur content was markedly elevated as a result of sulfonation. 3.1.6 SEM The surface of the VSC 450 °C precursor exhibits a relatively flat characteristic, with scattered mesopores (Fig. 5 (a) and (b)). In contrast, the surface of VSCS 450 °C was transformed into an irregular structure with a large number of microporous and mesopore after sulfonation, and gully-like an ant nest structure (Fig. 5 (c) and (d)). This may be caused by the corrosive effect of sulfuric acid on the material, which facilitated the entry of triglycerides and methanol into the catalyst and their subsequent adsorption on the surface for transesterification. The appearance of surface granular attachments should be the sulfonic acid groups that loaded on the precursor of VSC 450 °C. 3.2 Catalyst screening The initial assessment of the catalytic performance of VSCS solid acid was conducted through the transesterification reaction of glyceryl trioleate, which yielded a minimum of 91.82% and a maximum of 97.52%. This suggested that VSCS exhibited high catalytic activity for transesterification. On this basis, the VSCS were applied in the transesterification of WCO. The bar chart Fig. 6 , meticulously showed the high catalytic activity of VSCS for transesterification of WCO and the highest yield of 98.58% was achieved by using the VSCS 450 °C catalyst. Due to the lack of these carboxyl groups catalysts VSCS 600 °C and VSCS 750 °C have poorer performance than that of VSCS 450 °C. As the acidity of catalysts played an important role in the conversion of the transesterification, herein, such results may be related to their strong Brønsted acidity [35,36,45]. This phenomenon can be attributed to not only the elevated acidity of VSCS 450 °C, but also the considerable stability of the acid site. It elucidates why the acidity of VSCS 300 °C is the highest, yet its catalytic activity is not optimal. 3.3 Transesterification experiment 3.3.1 Influence of reaction conditions on catalyst activity 3.3.1.1 Influence of WCO/ MeOH molar ratio Considering that WCO/MeOH molar ratio was the most critical factor affecting transesterification efficiency, thus the WCO/MeOH molar ratio was adjusted from 1:10 to 1:50 in this section. As shown in Fig. 7 (a), with the increase of the WCO/MeOH molar ratio, the yield of FAME exhibited a significant upward trend, and reached a peak yield of 98.82% when the molar ratio reached 1:30. However, as the molar ratio was increased further, the yield of FAME began to decline. This phenomenon may be attributed to the fact that an increase in methanol concentration could potentially facilitate the reaction. However, the active site of the catalyst, has been occupied by an excess of methanol molecules, and the proton concentration was also be diluted by excessive methanol, weakened the protonation of triglyceride [46]. Therefore, the WCO/MeOH molar ratio of 1:30 was optimal and used for further explore. 3.3.1.2 Influence of reaction temperature To verify the dependency of FAME yield on reaction temperature, the experiments were conducted within a temperature range of 80 °C to 140 °C. Fig. 7 (b) illustrated that the conversion of triglyceride to FAME was indeed dependent on the reaction temperature. As the reaction temperature gradually increased, the conversion efficiency of triglycerides to FAME significantly improved and reached a maximum at 120 °C. This was primarily attributed to two factors. Firstly, under a higher temperature condition, the increased kinetic energy of the reactant molecules promoted the reaction rate. Secondly, higher temperature will reduce the viscosity of the reaction system, which facilitated effective contact and reaction of the reactant molecules, as described in Ref. [47]. In contrast to other works, this work demonstrated a reduction in temperature, resulting in an enhancement of the biodiesel yield [48,49]. For instance, Rhithuparna reported a 99.52% biodiesel yield at 160 °C, while this work attained the same yield at a significantly lower temperature of 120 °C. Subsequently, further detailed experimentation was conducted at 120 °C. 3.3.1.3 Influence of reaction time In order to investigate the influence of time on transesterification, a gradient of spanning from 8 h to 24 h has been established. Fig. 7(c) depicted the trend of the FAME yield of transesterification with reaction time. The yield of FAME exhibited a significant upward trend in 8 h and it continued to rise slowly until 12 h, with a maximum value of 99.84%. Nevertheless, when the reaction time continues to prolong, there was a slight decrease in the yield of FAME. It may be attributed to the fact that in the initial stage of the reaction, the higher concentration of reactant driven the reaction towards the production of FAME, resulting in a rapid increase in the yield of FAME. However, as the reaction proceeded, the increase in the concentration of glycerol accelerated the reverse transesterification, which in turn caused a decrease in the yield of FAME. As time progressed, the reaction will gradually approach equilibrium. Comparing with the work of Devi (the optimum reaction parameters for yield >99% were O/M: 1:45, catalyst amount: 20 wt.%, temperature: 160 °C and reaction time: 4 h), it was determined that reducing the other reaction parameters by appropriately extending the reaction time is a viable approach [50]. Additionally, prolonged exposure to elevated temperatures may result in the occurrence of other polymerization-related side reactions. Therefore, an appropriate reaction time would be 8–12 h. 3.3.1.4 Influence of catalyst amount The catalyst amount had a significant impact on the reaction efficiency, Fig. 7 (d) showed the trend for 12 h. When the amount of catalyst was only 2.4 wt.%, the yield of FAME was relatively low at 91.30%. However, as the catalyst amount was gradually increased, the yield of FAME also showed a steady upward trend. When the catalyst amount reached 7.2 wt.%, the yield of FAME reached its maximum value of 99.84%. This optimization effect could be attributed to the increased number of acid active of the catalyst, thereby enhancing the catalytic effect. It was slightly higher than the yield of 92.7% reported by Thushari for sulfonated carbon catalysts derived from coconut meal residue for biodiesel production [51]. Additionally, an 8 h trial also had been conducted. Unexpectedly, the other optimal condition was catalyst amount of 9.6 wt.%, and the yield of FAME was found to be 99.70%. Compared to Bastos' work, the optimal reaction parameters of this work showed an increase in the amount of catalyst (6 wt.% to 9.6 wt.%), but a substantial increase in the yield of biodiesel (91.8% to 99.70%) [52]. This indicated that the reaction time may be reduced by increasing the amount of catalyst in a way that achieves a higher level of industrial efficiency. 3.3.2 Artificial neural network fitting (ANN) As illustrated in Fig. 8 , the artificial neural network (ANN) model and its performance evaluation results are presented, and data for training artificial neural network are given in Table 3 . The structure of the ANN model, as shown in Fig. 8(a), comprises an input layer with four nodes, a hidden layer with fifteen nodes, and an output layer with a single node. The connections between layers are represented by weights (W) and biases (b). The scatter plots and fitted lines of output versus target values for the training, validation, testing, and overall datasets are presented in Fig. 8(b). The high correlation coefficients R (0.99923 for training, 0.99877 for validation, 0.99537 for testing, and 0.99873 overall) indicate excellent model-fitting performance. Furthermore, the comparison of predicted and actual fatty-acid methyl ester (FAME) yields in Fig. 8(c) validates the ANN model's high accuracy and reliability in predicting FAME yields, with close trends observed in the comparison. In conclusion, this ANN model features a reasonable structure, exhibits good fitting performance during training, validation, and testing, and its FAME-yield predictions are in good agreement with actual values, rendering it applicable for relevant research and applications such as FAME-yield prediction. 3.3.3 Reusability of the catalyst As the number of cyclic reactions increased, the effectiveness of the catalyst gradually decreased. The activity of the catalyst gradually decreased with an increase in the number of cycles was show in Fig. 9 . After five uses, there was a gradual decrease from 99.84% to 90.94% for FAME yield, and the yield reduction was not significant. A gradual decline in the catalytic activity after the cycle may due to the leaching of -SO3H group from carbon sheets during the transesterification. It has been documented that the extensive methanol could result in the leaching of the -SO3H group (Table 2, fresh S: 3.79 wt.%; used S: 0.84 wt.%). Moreover, a consequence of methanol reacting with the bonded -SO3H group, will lead to the formation of methyl sulfonate [53]. Overall, the cycling performance of the catalyst was still excellent. Compared with other similar solid acid catalysts, the catalyst has slightly higher recycling performance [16]. This phenomenon may be attributed to the substantial aromatization observed in the VSCS, as evidenced by the characterization data from FT-IR or TG. This has caused an increasing concentration of sulfonic and carboxylic group that facilitated the generation of a more acidic milieu, thereby enhancing the catalytic properties. Furthermore, the hydrogen bonding of the oxygen-containing groups (such as carboxyl and hydroxyl) in the structure is substantial, thereby ensuring a more robust and less susceptible to loss aromatization of the carbon sulfonic. 3.4 Characterization of biodiesel The physicochemical properties of WCO and biodiesel were listed in Table 4 . Both WCO and biodiesel are viscous dark yellow liquids. The WCO had an acid value of 5.00 mg KOH/g, while for biodiesel the acid value decreased to 0.28 mg KOH/g. It indicated that transesterification had been performed, and esterification of free fatty acids in WCO also occurred. Additionally, its kinematic viscosity decreased from 91.08 mm2/s to 10.76 mm2/s, which confirms transformation of WCO had been performed. This is compared to waste oil, fatty acid methyl esters have a smaller molecular weight and stronger fluidity, resulting in lower viscosity values. The density and saponification values of biodiesel and waste oil are similar. In conclusion, the physicochemical properties of biodiesel were similar to those reported in other works [42,54,55] and they also can met ASTM D6751 standard substantially. FT-IR was employed conduct a comprehensive investigation of the WCO and biodiesel (FAME). Fig. 10 displayed the corresponding spectral data, biodiesel and WCO had similar chemical structures, so their spectra were similar too. But, the observation of the wavenumber region of 1000–1500 cm−1 revealed significant spectral differences between WCO and biodiesel. The signal peak at 1435 cm−1 in the biodiesel spectrum correlated with the asymmetric stretching vibration of the -CH3 group, which was not detected in the WCO spectrum. The absorption peak at 1166 cm−1 of the WCO spectrum may be attributed to the stretching vibration of the -(O)C O-CH2 , which absent in the biodiesel spectrum [56]. In contrast, the absorption peak of the -(O)C O-CH3 at 1174 cm−1 in the biodiesel spectrum can be observed. So as this, FT-IR provided strong confirmation of the successful production of FAME. Biodiesel conversion could be verified with 1H NMR spectroscopy. As illustrated in Fig. 11 (a), the presence of multiple signals at 4.31 ppm and 4.17 ppm were attributed to the presence of glycerol framework protons, a characteristic feature of triglycerides. A more detailed examination of Fig. 11(b), a singlet peak at 3.66 ppm was observed, which was attributed to the characteristic signal of CH3O- protons [57]. Nevertheless, the signals at 4.31 ppm and 4.17 ppm absent in Fig. 11(b). Thereby, the successful synthesis of biodiesel (FAME) was corroborated by 1H NMR spectroscopy. However, 1H NMR can not only be used to qualitatively test the successful conversion of biodiesel, but also to qualitatively calculate the conversion rate of biodiesel. Many publications have reported and applied this method to calculate the conversion rate of biodiesel [33,34]. Applying this method, the conversion of biodiesel under optimal conditions was also calculated to be 100%, quantitatively confirming complete conversion. 3.5 Reaction mechanism The schematic diagram of the reaction mechanism is shown in Fig. 12 . In the VSCS structure, the carboxylic acid group and other oxygen-containing group exhibit distinctive chemical properties, enabling the effective capture of triglyceride and methanol through the formation of hydrogen bond, as described in Konwar's review [53]. Furthermore, VSCS possesses a considerable number of pores, which permit the entry of triglyceride and methanol, as well as the desorption of FAME. This significantly reduces the difficulty and threshold for chemical reactions to proceed. From the perspective of an in-depth analysis of microchemical reaction: Initially, triglycerides form hydrogen bonds with sulfonic and carboxylic group, then closely connect to the surface of solid acids, reaching a highly activated state. In this state, the sulfonic acid group significantly enhances the electron affinity of the ester group through the mediation of hydrogen bonds, making it more susceptible to nucleophilic attack by methanol molecules (Ⅰ). After activation, the methanol’s proton is transferred to the oxygen atom of the glycerol backbone, while the ester carbon undergoes a typical tetrahedral intermediate transition process (Ⅱ), ultimately producing one molecule of fatty acid methyl ester. Subsequently, the guiding effect of hydrogen bonds promotes the reaction to transfer to the next sulfonic site, continuing to catalyze the transesterification process of diglycerides (Ⅲ). In particular, the transesterification is facilitated by the synergistic action of the carboxylic acid group and the sulfonic acid group. The presence of carboxyl groups can enhance the acidity of the reaction system, and free protons are mainly distributed near the catalyst surface under the attraction of carboxyl or oxygen-containing groups. This will accelerate proton transfer, enhance protonation of ester groups, and promote the progress of ester exchange reactions. In addition, because of the hydrogen bonding between carboxyl and glycerol hydroxyl groups, the diglycerides produced by ester exchange do not immediately desorb from the catalyst surface. This makes it easy to interact with another adjacent sulfonic acid group and undergo ester exchange with methanol to produce monoglycerides. Likewise, the transesterification pathway of monoglycerides was then analogous to the previous process(Ⅳ). After transesterification is completed, the final products are three fatty acid methyl ester molecules and one glycerol molecule(Ⅴ), their desorption from the catalyst. These could also be demonstrated to some extent by the phenomena obtained from macroscopic observations. WCO initially combines with VSCS to form black emulsion droplets with an M/O structure (Ⅰ, Ⅱ, Ⅲ). As the reaction proceeded, numerous generated methyl oleate molecules aggregate with each other and gradually form an oil phase. After complete conversion of triglycerides, the black emulsion droplets also disappear, and the stratification phenomenon is obvious in the reaction system: the upper layer is mainly composed of methanol, glycerol, and some dissolved FAME, the middle layer is pure FAME, and the bottom layer is the catalyst (VSCS). 3.6 Green metrics parameters As illustrated in Table 5 , the ten green metrics demonstrate commendable performance. The transesterification of Waste Cooking Oil to biodiesel exhibits consistent values for yield (99.84%), atom economy (AE: 90.60%), renewable percentage (RP: 100%), and the reciprocal of stoichiometric factor (1/SF: 0.532) across no recovery, partial recovery, and total recovery scenarios (Fig. 13 ). In comparison with the AE: 85.00% and 1/SF: 0.500 findings reported in another work, this work's data demonstrates a marginal enhancement [26]. These constant metrics highlight the reaction’s intrinsic efficiency in converting renewable feedstocks, yet the gaps between 1/SF and ideal values (1.000). indicate unexploited potential for reducing non-stoichiometric relationships and suppressing reverse reaction pathways. In contrast, material recovery parameter (MRP: 0.457→0.799→1.000), reaction mass efficiency (RME: 0.249→0.386→0.621), environmental factor (E: 3.016→1.589→0.609), process mass intensity (PMI: 4.016→2.589→1.609), and solvent intensity (SI:1.355→0→0) vary significantly with recovery extent [23]. The upward trend in MRP and RME directly reflects enhanced resource utilization via material recycling, while declines in E and PMI signal reduced waste generation [28]. SI dropping to zero confirms the elimination of solvent-related environmental impacts, and the concurrent decrease in RI (correlated with PMI) denotes optimized ‘mass intensity’ of renewable resource input [27]. Collectively, material recovery emerges as the core lever for improving process greenness. Constant indicators establish the reaction’s inherent merits, whereas variable metrics underscore recovery’s critical role [23,24]. 4 Conclusions Using Vernicia montana seed shell as the raw material, a biochar-based solid acid catalyst was successfully prepared through carbonization and sulfonation processes. The catalyst exhibits amorphous structural characteristics composed of aromatic carbon. The sulfonic acid groups have been successfully loaded onto the catalyst with oxygen-containing functional groups have been retained. The structure provides a clear pathway for the effective contact between reactants and active site. In transesterification experiments, the yield of biodiesel reached 99.70 % at the optimal condition (WCO/MeOH molar ratio: 1:30, Temperature: 120 °C, Time: 8 h, Catalyst amount: 9.6 wt.%). Additionally, the ANN model demonstrated its efficacy in predicting FAME yield, underscoring its potential for optimizing reaction conditions. After five times reuse, the yield remained at a high level of 90.94 %. Green metrics of the transesterification reveal its potential for environmental sustainability, such as E = 0.609, AE = 90.60 %, Yield = 99.84 %, 1/SF = 0.532, MRP = 1.000, and RME = 0.621. Furthermore, the catalyst may also exhibit relatively high performance in fatty acid esterification. coredata.dc:description: Renewable energy has attracted widespread interest for fuel resources and environmental concerns. In this work, an eco-friendly novel catalyst (VSCS) was prepared from Vernicia montana seed shell via direct sulfonation. Subsequently, the catalytic performance was evaluated through the transesterification. The catalyst was characterized in order to elucidate the relationship between its catalytic performance and physicochemical structure. The VSCS catalyst achieved a high biodiesel yield (>90%) for glyceryl trioleate and Waste Cooking Oil (WCO). The catalyst possesses a considerable number of stable -SO3H, a sufficient quantity of -COOH, and exhibits a high acid content. Consequently, a 98.58% yield of biodiesel for WCO was obtained via VSCS 450 °C catalysis, and it reached 99.70% at the optimal conditions (catalyst amount of 9.6 wt.%, WCO/MeOH molar ratio of 1:30, at 120 °C for 8 h). Furthermore, an artificial neural network (ANN) model demonstrated the excellent performance for the prediction of FAME yield. Mechanism analysis shows that the synergistic effect of oxygen-containing group and sulfonic acid group, as well as facilitate physical adsorption, greatly facilitates transesterification. Green metrics indicated its sustainability, with low E-factor (0.609), high atom economy (90.60%) and desirable RME (0.621).

coredata.dc:title: Vernicia montana seed shell-derived solid acid for heterogeneous catalytic transesterification from Waste Cooking Oil to biodiesel: An artificial neural network-guided and sustainable approach
